description: Test code for arrays and dictionaries - runs a suite of tests on your calculator.
source:
# Test code for arrays and dictionaries
def t1():
  
  # List tests
  b = [1,2,3]
  b.append(4)
  passert(b[0] == 1)
  passert(b[1] == 2)
  passert(b[2] == 3)
  passert(b[3] == 4)
  passert(b[-1] == 4)
  b[2] = 333
  passert(b[2] == 333)
  passert(b[-2] == 333)
  passert(b[0] == 1)
  passert(b[-4] == 1)
  b = [1,2,3]
  passert(len(b) == 3)
  passert(b[-1] == 3)
  b.pop()
  passert(b[-1] == 2)
  
  # List alpha tests
  b = ['a', 'b', 'c']
  passert(b[0] == 'a')
  passert(b[-1] == 'c')
  b.append('fred')
  passert(b[3] == 'fred')
  passert(b[-1] == 'fred')
  
  # List by reference
  b2 = b  # anything we do to b2 is really done to b
  passert(len(b) == 4)
  passert(len(b2) == 4)
  b2.pop()
  passert(len(b2) == 3)
  passert(len(b) == 3)
  
  b = []
  passert(len(b) == 0)
  passert(len(b2) == 0)
  b.append('a')
  passert(len(b) == 1)
  passert(len(b2) == 1)
  passert(b[0] == 'a')
  passert(b2[0] == 'a')
  b2.append('b')
  passert(len(b) == 2)
  passert(len(b2) == 2)
  passert(b[-1] == 'b')
  passert(b2[-1] == 'b')

  # Dictionary tests
  d = {1:11,5:22}
  passert(d[5] == 22)
  passert(d[1] == 11)
  d[1] = 88
  passert(d[1] == 88)
  d[6] = 66
  passert(d[6] == 66)
  passert(d[5] == 22)
  passert(d[1] == 88)
  #PROMPT(A[1])
  #PROMPT(A[222])

  # Alpha Dictionary tests
  d = {'first':11,'second':22}
  passert(d['second'] == 22)
  passert(d['first'] == 11)
  d['another'] = 33
  passert(d['another'] == 33)
  
  print("all tests pass")
title: Test code for arrays and dictionaries
